page.title: List of songs recorded by Justin Timberlake

revision.comment: Disambiguating links to [[Sly, Slick and Wicked]] (link changed to [[Sly, Slick and Wicked (Cleveland band)]]; link changed to [[Sly, Slick and Wicked (Cleveland band)]]) using [[User:Qwertyytrewqqwerty/DisamAssist|DisamAssist]].
revision.text:
[[File:Justin Timberlake 2014 February 3.jpg|upright|thumb|Timberlake in 2014]] American singer-songwriter [[Justin Timberlake]] has written and recorded material for his five studio albums. Timberlake released his solo debut studio album, ''[[Justified (album)|Justified]]'', in November 2002.{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/Justified-Justin-Timberlake/dp/B00006RY20/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1415558996&sr=8-1&keywords=justified+justin+timberlake|title=Justified by Justin Timberlake |accessdate=November 3, 2014|date=2002-11-04 }} Most of the album was produced by [[The Neptunes]], with additional collaborators including [[Brian McKnight]], [[Scott Storch]], [[Timbaland]], and [[The Underdogs (production team)|The Underdogs]]. "[[Like I Love You]]", written by Timberlake, Chad Hugo and Pharrell Williams. "[[Cry Me a River (Justin Timberlake song)|Cry Me a River]]", produced by Timbaland,{{cite AV media notes|others=Justin Timberlake |title=[[Justified (album)|Justified]]|year=2002|type= inlay cover|publisher= [[Jive Records]]}} is a R&B song about a brokenhearted man who moves on from his past. A ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' reviewer called the song a "breakup [[aria]]."{{cite news|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/the-500-greatest-songs-of-all-time-20110407/justin-timberlake-cry-me-a-river-19691231 |title=500 Greatest Songs of All the Time: Justin Timberlake, 'Cry Me a River' |work=[[Rolling Stone]] |accessdate=May 16, 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120411013122/http://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/the-500-greatest-songs-of-all-time-20110407/justin-timberlake-cry-me-a-river-19691231 |archivedate=April 11, 2012 |url-status=unfit }} Timberlake, Hugo and Williams also wrote "[[Rock Your Body]]" and "[[Señorita (Justin Timberlake song)|Señorita]]". His second studio album, ''[[FutureSex/LoveSounds]]'', was released in September 2006.{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/Future-Love-Sounds-Justin-Timberlake/dp/B000GG46NU/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1415559028&sr=8-1&keywords=future+sex+%2F+love+sounds+justin+timberlake|title=Future Sex / Love Sounds |accessdate=November 3, 2014|date=2006-09-11 }} It infuses [[contemporary R&B|R&B]] and [[pop music|pop]] with [[techno]], [[funk]], and elements of [[rock music|rock]], the last being the genre that was the main inspiration of Timberlake during the album's recording. The [[alternative R&B|electro R&B]] song "[[SexyBack]]", is built around a pounding bass beat, electronic chords, and beat box sounds. Andrew Murfett of ''[[The Age]]'' wrote that the song was a "raunchy club banger that slyly suppresses" Timberlake's customary falsetto. "[[My Love (Justin Timberlake song)|My Love]]" is a [[synthpop]]-influenced, [[contemporary R&B|R&B]] and [[hip hop music|hip hop]] song.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/02/09/arts/music/09timb.html?_r=1|title=He's Bringing Commitment Back (and Not in a Box) |last=Michel|first=Sia|date=2007-02-09|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=2009-05-21}} "[[What Goes Around... Comes Around]]", is a pop-R&B song performed in a slow manner{{cite web |title=Justin Timberlake Digital Sheet Music: What Goes Around |url=http://www.musicnotes.com/sheetmusic/mtd.asp?ppn=MN0056580 |work=Musicnotes |accessdate=2008-02-13|date = 2007-03-05}} and was described by some music critics as a "sequel" to his 2002 song "Cry Me a River". "[[LoveStoned|LoveStoned/I Think She Knows]]" is an R&B and [[art rock]] song{{cite web|last=Politi |first=Daniel |url=http://www.slate.com/articles/arts/music_box/2006/09/justin_in_timbaland.html |title=The new Justin Timberlake album reviewed. – Slate Magazine |publisher=Slate.com |date= |accessdate=June 9, 2013}} that contains sexually suggestive lyrics and includes "human beatbox sounds" in its composition.{{cite journal|first=Martin|last=Edlund|title=One for the Ages|date=September 5, 2006|journal=[[The New York Sun]]|page=14}} ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' described the song as "flowing from hip-hop bump-and-grind to an ambient wash of Interpol-inspired guitar drone."{{cite news|accessdate=September 1, 2011|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/100-best-albums-of-the-2000s-20110718/justin-timberlake-futuresex-lovesounds-19691231|title=Justin Timberlake, 'FutureSex/LoveSounds' |work=Rolling Stone|publisher=Jann S. Wenner |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120415032142/http://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/100-best-albums-of-the-2000s-20110718/justin-timberlake-futuresex-lovesounds-19691231 |archivedate = April 15, 2012}} Timberlake co-wrote and appeared as a featured vocalist on several songs, including "[[Give It to Me (Timbaland song)|Give It to Me]]" with [[Timbaland]], "[[Ayo Technology]]" with [[50 Cent]], "[[4 Minutes (Madonna song)|4 Minutes]]" with [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]] and "[[Dead and Gone]]" with [[T.I.]]. In March 2013, after a seven-year hiatus from his solo music career, Timberlake released his third studio album, ''[[The 20/20 Experience]]''.{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.de/20-Experience-Justin-Timberlake/dp/B00BCZU8WM|title=The 20/20 Experience 1 of 2|accessdate=November 3, 2014}} The record incorporates [[neo soul]] styles with elements of older [[Rock music|rock]] and [[soul music]]; its lyrics discuss themes of romance and sex. As a songwriter, Timberlake mainly collaborated with [[Timbaland]], [[J-Roc (record producer)|Jerome "J-Roc" Harmon]] and [[James Fauntleroy]], and co-produced the tracks along with Timbaland and Harmon. "[[Suit & Tie]]", is a mid-tempo [[Contemporary R&B|R&B]] song, that incorporates a "slow-drawl" consisting of slowed down synths and "slightly out of time" drum claps, similar to the [[Chopped and Screwed]].{{cite web|last=Cragg |first=Michael |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2013/jan/14/new-music-justin-timberlake |title=New music: Justin Timberlake – Suit & Tie feat Jay Z |publisher=Guardian |date=January 10, 2013 |accessdate=January 14, 2013}} "[[Mirrors (Justin Timberlake song)|Mirrors]]", is a [[progressive pop]] and R&B track, lyrically a love song about person's other half. "[[Let the Groove Get In]]" is a [[Dance music|dance]] and [[Pop music|pop]] song accompanied by canned [[French horn|horns]], propulsive percussion and Timberlake's harmonized voice over a pop arrangement.{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/review/1551360/justin-timberlake-the-2020-experience-track-by-track-review|title=Justin Timberlake, 'The 20/20 Experience': Track-By-Track Review|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]] |last=Lipshutz|first=Jason|date=March 12, 2013|accessdate=April 6, 2015}} In September 2013, Timberlake released the second half of the project, ''[[The 20/20 Experience – 2 of 2]]''.{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.de/dp/B00DZS9XSY|title=The 20/20 Experience - 2 of 2 (Standard Edition)|accessdate=November 3, 2014|date=2013-09-27}} It included the pop ballad "[[Not a Bad Thing]]" and the [[Gospel blues|gospel-blues]] "[[Drink You Away]]".{{cite news|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2013-09-30/entertainment/chi-justin-timberlake-review-20130929_1_20-20-experience-wallrdquo-producer-timbaland |title=Justin Timberlake, 'The 20/20 Experience 2 of 2' review|work=[[Chicago Tribune]] |last=Kot|first=Greg|date=September 30, 2015|accessdate=November 5, 2015}} Timberlake also appeared on the songs "[[Love Never Felt So Good]]" from ''[[Xscape (album)|Xscape]]'' and "[[Holy Grail (Jay Z song)|Holy Grail]]" from ''[[Magna Carta Holy Grail]]''. For the [[Post-disco|disco-pop]] song "[[Can't Stop the Feeling!]]", Timberlake collaborated in the songwriting and production with [[Max Martin]] and [[Shellback (record producer)|Shellback]].{{cite web | url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/pop/7357815/justin-timberlake-cant-stop-the-feeling-new-song | title=Justin Timberlake Delivers Delightful Single 'Can't Stop The Feeling!': Watch | work=Billboard | date=May 6, 2016 | accessdate=May 6, 2016 | author=Platon, Adelle}} The production of his fifth studio album ''[[Man of the Woods]]'' (2018) was handled by Timberlake, [[The Neptunes]], [[Timbaland]], [[Danja (record producer)|Danja]], and [[Rob Knox (producer)|Rob Knox]].
